Description: Although epidemiological studies link bacterial infections to cancers, the role of bacteria in developing cancer is generally considered to be non-specific, caused by induction of chronic inflammation by bacterial infection. However, recent studies have revealed that several bacteria can variably manipulate their infection host cells and such bacterial manipulations can contribute to the development of specific types of cancers. Especially, the oncogenic relationship between bacteria and humans has been shown in Helicobacter pylori and Salmonella typhi infections. Chronic infection with H. pylori plays a critical role in the development of most, if not all, human gastric cancers. H. pylori can also induce MALT lymphoma in infected individuals. S. typhi infection has been associated with the development of gallbladder cancer. Nevertheless, molecular mechanisms by which certain bacteria can transform human cells remain largely ununderstood. In this session, mechanisms by which a particular bacterial infection leads to neoplastic transformation of infected host cells will be discussed.
